thread.title: Verizon Got Into A Twitter Beef With T-Mobile Over Their Super Bowl Commercial And Things Got Weird
thread.title_full: Verizon Got Into A Twitter Beef With T-Mobile Over Their Super Bowl Commercial And Things Got Weird

author: Stacey Ritzen
title: Verizon Got Into A Twitter Beef With T-Mobile Over Their Super Bowl Commercial And Things Got Weird
text:
‚ù§Ô∏è you @Kristenschaaled but if you want the pain of overages, @Verizon can provide lots of it. #TMobileONE =no pain! #TheSafeWordisUnlimited pic.twitter.com/7MiwtbnuCN 
‚Äî T-Mobile (@TMobile) February 5, 2017 

T-Mobile went all in and aired not one, not two, but three star-studded commercials to push the company‚Äôs new unlimited data plan during Sunday night‚Äôs Super Bowl. One spot featured Justin Bieber and Rob ‚ÄúGronk‚Äù Gronkowski of the New England Patriots dancing, while another had the comedic duo Martha Stewart and Snoop Dogg throwing around some tongue-in-cheek marijuana euphemisms , and finally there was the above 50 Shades of Grey style parody starring Kristen Schaal who enjoyed being punished for her naughty, naughty Verizon Wireless data overages.
It was the latter that the rival cell carrier seemed to take the most umbrage with, and Schaal and the T-Mobile official Twitter account indulging in some playful back and forth banter during the game only seemed to twist the knife deeper.
. @Verizon overages hurt so bad. Do you punish your customers that way, @TMobile ? #TheSafeWordisUnlimited 
‚Äî Kristen Schaal (@kristenschaaled) February 5, 2017 
Sorry @Kristenschaaled but with our UNLIMITED network, you won‚Äôt feel the pain of overages. Can we still be friends? #TheSafeWordisUnlimited https://t.co/ZpZpMqMqdS 
‚Äî T-Mobile (@TMobile) February 6, 2017 


Hate to break it to you @KristenSchaaled , but #TMobileONE won‚Äôt punish you with overages. #TheSafeWordisUnlimited pic.twitter.com/8ZRodPwQ5F 
‚Äî T-Mobile (@TMobile) February 6, 2017 
I‚Äôve been streaming video all night and @Verizon punished me with overages! @TMobile can you teach me a lesson too? #TheSafeWordisUnlimited 
‚Äî Kristen Schaal (@kristenschaaled) February 6, 2017 
I heard @Verizon dominates customers with taxes and fees. @JohnLegere you into that sort of thing? Say yes! #TheSafeWordisUnlimited pic.twitter.com/6CZnMs4acS 
‚Äî Kristen Schaal (@kristenschaaled) February 6, 2017 
Overages from @Verizon are like little scoldings on my bill. @TMobile are you gonna get tough with me? #TheSafeWordisUnlimited 
‚Äî Kristen Schaal (@kristenschaaled) February 6, 2017 
Think you‚Äôve had too much? Are you close to being finished‚Ä¶ with limits? You won‚Äôt get punished with #TMobileONE #TheSafeWordisUnlimited pic.twitter.com/k1KhRawIML 
‚Äî T-Mobile (@TMobile) February 6, 2017 


Much like a certain thin-skinned president we know, this all became too much for Verizon, and whoever runs the corporate Twitter account fired back with some, uh, interesting innuendo.
Yes @Tmobile , we're into BDSM. Bigger coverage map, Devastating Speed, and Massive capacity.
‚Äî Verizon (@verizon) February 6, 2017 
Unfortunately no one will hear your safe word if you're on @Tmobile . ü§ê
‚Äî Verizon (@verizon) February 6, 2017 

Well that got pretty weird, pretty fast. But things got even weirder when the Verizon customer service Twitter account started trolling Schaal as well.
Guys‚Ä¶ Verizon customer service just contacted Kristen. This is really happening‚Ä¶ #TheSafeWordisUnlimited pic.twitter.com/dZ9TubCca1 
‚Äî T-Mobile (@TMobile) February 6, 2017 

Thankfully T-Mobile decided to take the high road in their response, because that could have really gone to some dark places.
They broke our Jealousy-O-Meter! Those aren't cheap, Vzw‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Yh7MjGtcf4 
‚Äî T-Mobile (@TMobile) February 6, 2017
